fields._release_notes_rendered:
Welcome to phpMyAdmin 4.3. This release contains many bug fixes and several
new features including the work done by our Google Summer of Code (GSoC)
students, and is the first release since the hiring of a full-time
developer. Read on for more information or skip directly to the
download at https://sourceforge.net/projects/phpmyadmin/files or always read
the complete list of changes by referring to the changelog.php or ChangeLog
files, included with this release.

First, some information on our featured GSoC projects:

Smita Kumari worked on two structure tools,
1) “a feature that enables a user to maintain a central list of columns per database
to avoid similar name for the same data element and bring consistency of data
type for the same data element.”

2) Automated normalization is known as "Improve table structure" within phpMyAdmin.
It helps to bring the table structure upto Third Normal Form. A wizard is
presented to user which asks questions about the elements during the various
steps for normalization and a new structure is proposed accordingly to bring the
table optionally into the First/Second/Third Normal form.

Edward Cheng implemented a component which provides easy access to a console,
including bookmarking and a history viewer.

Chirayu Chiripal and Ashutosh Dhundhara both worked on many feature improvements.
These improvements may not be glamorous but feature some much needed maintenance
and minor improvements.

Behind the scenes, Dhananjay Nakrani has improved the error reporting server,
an optional reporting feature allowing users to automatically submit error
reports directly to the phpMyAdmin developers. Now, PHP errors can also be reported.

Additional behind the scenes work was done by Bimal Yashodha to refactor the code
behind the Designer interface. Most of these improvements are transparent to users
but help ease the maintenance  required on this portion of the code.

Our second piece of exciting news is that this release includes many improvements
thanks to our new full-time developer, Madhura Jayaratne.

"I am so excited to be working for phpMyAdmin as a contract developer and since
I started working, my focus has mainly been on stabilizing the code for the upcoming
version 4.3 release. This involved fixing a number of bugs as well as improving
performance, which was due for some time.”

The biggest improvement Madhura has brought to 4.3 is increased speed and performance
when operating with many (thousands) databases, such as in a shared hosting environment.

Some of the new features are:
* Smart sorting for int keys
* Confirmation message when dropping user(s)
* Confirm dialog on accidentally leaving a page
* Allow clicking an approximate row count to get a correct one
* Support for editing binary fields in hexadecimal
* MariaDB 10+ multi-master replication support
* Allow saving query charts as images
* Use aliases in SQL export for tables and columns
* Export with table/column name changes
* Dynamic process list
* Drag and Drop SQL import
* Preview SQL instead of executing it
* Run SQL query: Allow rollback for InnoDB tables
* Zeroconf PMA tables support
* Regexp replace
* Avoid session timeout when user is active
* MySQL 5.7.5 compatibility
* Avoid session timeout when user is active
* Multiple-column foreign key relation
* Charts for data in  format
* Range Search Capability
* Improvements for the table editor (index creation)
* PHP OpenSSL support for cookie encryption/decryption

The phpMyAdmin team

Welcome to phpMyAdmin 3.5.3, a bugfix release with minor security fixes. This release no longer contains the Highcharts library (which caused a licensing problem).

3.5.3.0 (2012-10-08)
- bug #3539044 [interface] Browse mode "Show" button gives blank page if no resu
lts anymore
- bug #3534979 [interface] Copy Database Ajax feedback vanishes long before copy
ing is done
- bug #3527531 [interface] GC-maxlifetime warning incorrectly displayed
- bug #3526916 [interface] Search fails with JS error when tooltips disabled
- bug #3544366 [interface] Event comments not saved
- bug #3549084 [edit] Can't enter date directly when editing inline
- bug #3548491 [interface] Inline query editor doesn't work from search results
- bug #3547825 [edit] BLOB download no longer works
- bug #3541966 [config] Error in generated configuration arrray
- bug #3553551 [GUI] Invalid HTML code in multi submits confirmation form
- [interface] Designer sometimes places tables on the top menu
- bug #3546277 [core] Call to undefined function __() when config file has wrong
 permissions
- bug #3540922 [edit] Error searching table with many fields
- bug #3555104 [edit] Cannot copy a DB with table and views
- bug #3559925 [privileges] Incorrect updating of the list of users
- bug #3561224 [edit] cell edit date field with empty date fills in current date
- bug #3559955 [edit] current_date from function drop down fails on update
- bug #3562472 add support for Solaris and FreeBSD system load and memory displa
y in server status
- bug #3553068 [import] Table import from XML file fails
- replace Highcharts with jqplot for Display chart
- bug #3567684 [edit] Pasting value doesn't clear null checkbox
- bug #3570786 [edit] Datepicker for date and datetime fields is broken

fields._release_notes_rendered:
Welcome to phpMyAdmin 4.4.0, an incremental feature release including many bug fixes.

A complete list of new features and bugs fixed is available in the ChangeLog file or changelog.php included with this release.

A few highlights:
* Rename configuration directive from $cfg['NavigationTreeDisableDatabaseExpansion']
  to $cfg['NavigationTreeEnableExpansion'] -- if used, please update your config.inc.php
* Move the SQL scripts to create phpMyAdmin configuration storage from 'examples' to 'sql' directory
* Upgrade Recaptcha to version 2 of the API
* Added support for the SSL GRANT option
* Improvements to the table structure and tracking pages
* Improvements to the console feature
* Improvements to the ZeroConf feature

There are many more; please refer to the ChangeLog for full details.

As always, downloads are available at https://www.phpmyadmin.net

The phpMyAdmin Team

et NULL

fields._release_notes_rendered:
Welcome to phpMyAdmin 3.5.0; here are the major new features:

* browse-mode improvements
** grid editing
** remember recent tables
** remember last sort order by table
** flexible column width
** reorder columns
** more compact navigation bar
* AJAXification of many operations
* reorganised server status page, with server monitoring
* improved support for stored routines, events and triggers
* openGIS support
* zoom-search in table search
* Drizzle support
* improved ENUM/SET editor

fields._release_notes_rendered:
Welcome to phpMyAdmin 4.1.0.

This release contains many improvements and bug fixes. With this release the minimum supported PHP version is now 5.3 and the minimum MySQL version is 5.5.
 
A few highlights include:
* Allow specifying a port when connecting to the controlhost
* User interface improvements to server privileges, view creation, the
Operations tab, Relation View, and when creating new users.
* Added support for AES_ENCRYPT on BLOB columns
* Added support for relations with ndbcluser
* Added optional ReCAPTCHA support during login
* Added support for fractional seconds in time, datetime, and timestamp
columns
* Added find and replace by column
* Added the Error Reporting Component, an optional feature allowing
users to report certain errors directly to the phpMyAdmin bug team.
* Added configurable menus (so an administrator can hide certain
features)
 
The SQP and MySQLManual* configuration directives have been removed.
 
For complete information, please view changelog.php or the ChangeLog file,
included with this release.
fields.release_notes:

Operations tab, Relation View, and when creating new users.
* Added support for AES_ENCRYPT on BLOB columns
* Added support for relations with ndbcluser
* Added optional ReCAPTCHA support during login
* Added support for fractional seconds in time, datetime, and timestamp
columns
* Added find and replace by column
* Added the Error Reporting Component, an optional feature allowing
users to report certain errors directly to the phpMyAdmin bug team.
* Added configurable menus (so an administrator can hide certain
features)
 
The SQP and MySQLManual* configuration directives have been removed.
 
For complete information, please view changelog.php or the ChangeLog file,
included with this release.

Welcome to phpMyAdmin 4.2.0, containing new features and fixes.

4.2.0.0 (2014-05-08)
+ rfe #1403 Export only triggers
+ rfe #1483 Export Server/Database/Table without triggers
+ rfe #1662 Add table comment tool tip in database structure page
+ rfe #1447 Single table for display Character Sets and Collations
+ rfe #1455 Display icons/text/both for the table row actions
+ rfe #1473 Transformation to convert Boolean value to text
- bug #4157 Changing users password will delete it
+ rfe #1474 Text transformation combines Append and Prepend
+ Added warning about the mysql extension being deprecated
  and removed the extension directive
+ Added support for scatter charts
+ rfe #1478 Make Column Headings Sticky
+ rfe #1480 Enhance privileges initials table
+ rfe #1472 [interface] Break "Edit privileges" with sub-menus
+ rfe #1466 Minor refactoring required
+ rfe #1004 Create indexes at the end in SQL export
+ rfe #1479 Relations edit form for larger monitors
+ rfe #1475 Inline query box vertical resize
+ rfe #1500 [interface] Add bottom border to top menu container
+ rfe #1498 Add datepicker for 'TIME' type
- bug #4237 HTTP Referer disclosure in SQL links
+ rfe       Show full names on navigation hover
+ rfe #1505 Behaviour on click on a routine in nav panel
+ rfe #1418 Support more than one separating character on CSV import
+ rfe #569  Load/Save Query By Example
- bug #4281 Grid edit ENUM field, dialog disappears when trying to select
- bug #4304 DB export using zip compression generates an empty archive
+ rfe #1508 confirmation message at the top
- bug #4306 breadcrubs wrong on table create
+ rfe #1511 better validate database name for copying
+ rfe #1510 Database tab "Drop" button should be a link
+ rfe #1513 Highlight required form fields after failed submission
+ rfe #1460 Redirect to login page after session has expired
- bug #4316 Grid edit: can't change month on date fields
+ rfe #1501 add maxlength by field with length-spec
+ rfe #1512 Import happily doesn't do anything with no file name provided
+ rfe #1514 Add function to all the insert boxes automatically
+ rfe #1515 Option to skip tables larger than n
+ rfe #1486 Possibility of disabling database expansion
+ rfe #1476 Favourite tables select box
+ rfe #420  $cfg['CharEditing']='textarea' for structure edit
+ rfe #1329 Avoid editing of fields which are part of relation
+ rfe       [interface] Highlight active left menu item in setup
+ rfe       Filter on-screen rows during Browse
  Removed support for SQL Validator (SOAP service no longer offered)
- bug #4352 Settings > Manage: incorrect messages
- bug #4337 "More" in Actions area doesn't collapse to fit available space
- bug #4375 Group two DB, one's name is the prefix of the other one
- bug #4070 Confusing database/table grouping
- bug #4366 Creating Index doesn't update index-list

fields._description_rendered: With a crafted database or table name it is possible to trigger an XSS in SQL debug output when enabled and in server monitor page when viewing and analysing executed queries.
fields.affected: Versions 4.0.x (prior to 4.0.10.5), 4.1.x (prior to 4.1.14.6) and 4.2.x (prior to 4.2.10.1) are affected.
fields.description: With a crafted database or table name it is possible to trigger an XSS in SQL debug output when enabled and in server monitor page when viewing and analysing executed queries.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 4.0.10.5 or newer, or 4.1.14.6 or newer, or 4.2.10.1 or newer, or apply the patch listed below.
fields.summary: XSS vulnerabilities in SQL debug output and server monitor page.
fields.mitigation:
This vulnerability can be triggered only by someone who is logged in to phpMyAdmin, as the usual token protection prevents non-logged-in users from accessing the required pages.
Moreover, debugging SQL is a developer option which is disabled by default and expected to be disabled in production environments.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be non critical.

fields._description_rendered:
• In the setup/index.php, using a crafted # hash with a Javascript event, untrusted JS code could be executed.
  • In the Display chart view, a chart title containing HTML code was rendered unescaped, leading to possible JavaScript code execution via events.
  • A malicious user with permission to create databases or users having HTML tags in their name, could trigger an XSS vulnerability by issuing a sleep query with a long delay. In the server status monitor, the query parameters were shown unescaped.
  • By configuring a malicious URL for the phpMyAdmin logo link in the navigation sidebar, untrusted script code could be executed when a user clicked the logo.
  • The setup field for "List of trusted proxies for IP allow/deny" Ajax validation code returned the unescaped input on errors, leading to possible JavaScript execution by entering arbitrary HTML.
fields.affected: Versions 3.5.x (prior to 3.5.8.2) and 4.0.x (prior to 4.0.4.2) are affected.
fields.description:
• In the setup/index.php, using a crafted # hash with a Javascript event, untrusted JS code could be executed.
  • In the Display chart view, a chart title containing HTML code was rendered unescaped, leading to possible JavaScript code execution via events.
  • A malicious user with permission to create databases or users having HTML tags in their name, could trigger an XSS vulnerability by issuing a sleep query with a long delay. In the server status monitor, the query parameters were shown unescaped.
  • By configuring a malicious URL for the phpMyAdmin logo link in the navigation sidebar, untrusted script code could be executed when a user clicked the logo.
  • The setup field for "List of trusted proxies for IP allow/deny" Ajax validation code returned the unescaped input on errors, leading to possible JavaScript execution by entering arbitrary HTML.
fields.solution:
Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 3.5.8.2 or 4.0.4.2 or newer or apply the patches
listed below.
fields.summary: 5 XSS vulnerabilities in setup, chart display, process list, and logo link.
fields.mitigation:
The stored XSS vulnerabilities can be triggered only by someone who logged in to phpMyAdmin,
as the usual token protection prevents non-logged-in users from accessing the required forms.
The setup vulnerabilities can only be triggered when a crafted value is entered by the user.
fields.references: Thanks to Emanuel Bronshtein for reporting these issues.
fields.severity: We consider these vulnerabilities to be non critical.

fields._description_rendered: phpMyAdmin used eval function to fill some values and one parameter used there was table name. When specifying specially formatted table name, this could lead to eval attacker code. However this requires also a modified MySQL server, that will return these table names, as normally MySQL doesn't allow it. With conjunction to not checking input variables, attacker can make phpMyAdmin use patched MySQL server he wants.
fields.affected: All releases starting with 2.5.1 up to and including 2.5.7.
fields.description: phpMyAdmin used eval function to fill some values and one parameter used there was table name. When specifying specially formatted table name, this could lead to eval attacker code. However this requires also a modified MySQL server, that will return these table names, as normally MySQL doesn't allow it. With conjunction to not checking input variables, attacker can make phpMyAdmin use patched MySQL server he wants.
fields.solution:
If you are vulnerable to this issue, we recommend to enable light left
frame mode, which disables eval code. We strongly advise everyone to
upgrade to CVS HEAD or to the next version of phpMyAdmin, which is to be
released soon.
fields.summary:
When faking table with specific name, an attacker can make phpMyAdmin
to execute arbitrary php code and add custom server configuration.
fields.references: https://www.securityfocus.com/archive/1/367486
fields.unaffected:
All releases older than 2.5.1.
CVS HEAD has been fixed.
The upcoming 2.5.7-pl1 release.
fields.severity:
Default configuration is not affected by this issue, it can happen only
when $$cfg['LeftFrameLight'] is FALSE. When this condition is met,
attacker can execute arbitrary php code which is shipped by his patched
MySQL version. If php is running in safe mode or there is firewall not
allowing outgoing connections to outside machines, this issue can not
cause any harm. As this can cause serious problems, we consider this
issue as critical.

fields._description_rendered: It was possible to conduct a XSS attack using error messages in PHP backtrace.
fields.description: It was possible to conduct a XSS attack using error messages in PHP backtrace.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 3.3.6 or newer or apply patch listed below.
fields.mitigation:
Additional steps from administrator are required to actually exploit this
issue (phpMyAdmin error reporting and collection needs to be enabled, what 
is against recommendation for production setup).
fields.references: Thanks to Aung Khant from YGN Ethical Hacker Group, Myanmar for reporting this issue.
fields.unaffected: Branch 2.11.x is not affected by this.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be non critical.

fields._description_rendered: The export script generates global variables from those present in the $$_POST superglobal. This may lead to other exploits in the export script.
fields.description: The export script generates global variables from those present in the $$_POST superglobal. This may lead to other exploits in the export script.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 4.0.0-rc3 or newer.
fields.mitigation: This vulnerability can be triggered only by someone who logged in to phpMyAdmin, as the usual token protection prevents non-logged-in users to access the required form.
fields.references: Thanks to Janek Vind for reporting this issue.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be serious.

fields._description_rendered: By deceiving a user to click on a crafted URL, it is possible to alter the configuration file being generated with phpMyAdmin setup.
fields.affected: Versions 4.0.x (prior to 4.0.10.10), 4.2.x (prior to 4.2.13.3), 4.3.x (prior to 4.3.13.1) and 4.4.x (prior to 4.4.6.1) are affected.
fields.description: By deceiving a user to click on a crafted URL, it is possible to alter the configuration file being generated with phpMyAdmin setup.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 4.0.10.10 or newer, or 4.2.13.3 or newer, or 4.3.13.1 or newer, or 4.4.6.1 or newer, or apply the patch listed below.
fields.mitigation:
This vulnerability only affects the configuration file generation process and does not affect 
the effective configuration file. Moreover, the configuration file being generated is at risk 
only during the period when it's writable.
fields.references: Thanks to Inti De Ceukelaire (https://ceukelai.re) for reporting this vulnerability.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be non critical.

fields._description_rendered: By calling some scripts that are part of phpMyAdmin in an unexpected way (especially scripts in the libraries subdirectory), it is possible to trigger phpMyAdmin to display a PHP error message which contains the full path of the directory where phpMyAdmin is installed.
fields.description: By calling some scripts that are part of phpMyAdmin in an unexpected way (especially scripts in the libraries subdirectory), it is possible to trigger phpMyAdmin to display a PHP error message which contains the full path of the directory where phpMyAdmin is installed.
fields.solution: Apply the PHP manual recommendations. Note that it's possible to apply a PHP configuration directive to a specific directory (see References).
fields.mitigation: This path disclosure is possible on servers where the recommended setting of the PHP configuration directive <tt>display_errors</tt> is set to <tt>on</tt>, which is against the recommendations given in the PHP manual.
fields.references:
About the display_errors directive:
https://www.php.net/manual/en/ref.errorfunc.php
How to apply the directive to a specific directory:
https://www.php.net/manual/en/configuration.changes.php
fields.severity: We consider those vulnerabilities to be minor (see Mitigation factor).

fields._description_rendered: phpMyAdmin has a number of mechanisms to avoid a clickjacking attack, however these mechanisms either work only in modern browser versions, or can be bypassed.
fields.description: phpMyAdmin has a number of mechanisms to avoid a clickjacking attack, however these mechanisms either work only in modern browser versions, or can be bypassed.
fields.solution:
Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 4.0.5 or newer or apply the patches listed below. We 
have no solution for 3.5.x, due to the proposed solution requiring JavaScript.
We don't want to introduce a dependency to JavaScript in the 3.5.x family.
fields.references: Thanks to Emanuel Bronshtein for reporting this issue. For more details, please refer to this report.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability serious.

fields._description_rendered: phpMyAdmin used to automatically create temporary world writable directory what could lead to possible misuse of it.
fields.description: phpMyAdmin used to automatically create temporary world writable directory what could lead to possible misuse of it.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 3.0.0 or 2.11.10.
fields.references: We wish to thank to Thijs Kinkhorst for pointing out this issue.
fields.unaffected: 3.x releases are not affected.
fields.severity: We consider these vulnerabilities to be not critical.

fields._description_rendered: Crafted values entered in the setup interface can produce XSS; also, if the config directory exists and is writeable, the XSS payload can be saved to this directory.
fields.description: Crafted values entered in the setup interface can produce XSS; also, if the config directory exists and is writeable, the XSS payload can be saved to this directory.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 3.4.9 or newer or apply the related patch listed below.
fields.mitigation:
The documentation warns against leaving this directory writeable; also
a warning appears on the home page. Also, this XSS would target only the
users who visit /setup.
fields.references: Thanks to Jason Leyrer of Trustwave SpiderLabs for finding this issue and to Robert Foggia (same company) for contacting us.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be non critical.

fields._description_rendered: When navigating into the database triggers page, it is possible to trigger an XSS with a crafted trigger name.
fields.affected: Versions 4.0.x (prior to 4.0.10.1), 4.1.x (prior to 4.1.14.2) and 4.2.x (prior to 4.2.6) are affected.
fields.description: When navigating into the database triggers page, it is possible to trigger an XSS with a crafted trigger name.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 4.0.10.1 or newer, or 4.1.14.2 or newer, or 4.2.6 or newer, or apply the patch listed below.
fields.summary: Self-XSS due to unescaped HTML output in database triggers page.
fields.mitigation: This vulnerability can be triggered only by someone who is logged in to phpMyAdmin, as the usual token protection prevents non-logged-in users from accessing the required page.
fields.references: Thanks to Frans Rosén of detectify for reporting this vulnerability.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be non critical.

fields._description_rendered: During the course of phpMyAdmin 2.6.4 development, some XSS vulnerabilities were fixed but were not documented here. The cookie-based login panel, the title parameter and the table creation dialog were vulnerable.
fields.affected: We did not make an extensive verification on this. Probably all previous versions are affected.
fields.description: During the course of phpMyAdmin 2.6.4 development, some XSS vulnerabilities were fixed but were not documented here. The cookie-based login panel, the title parameter and the table creation dialog were vulnerable.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 2.6.4-pl4.
fields.severity: We consider these vulnerabilities to be serious.

fields._description_rendered:
We received a security advisory from Nicolas Gregoire (exaprobe.com) about those vulnerabilities and we wish to thank him for his work. Both vulnerabilites can be exploited only on a web server where PHP safe mode is off. The vulnerabilities apply to those points:

  1. Command execution: since phpMyAdmin 2.6.0-pl2, on a system where external MIME-based transformations are activated, an attacker can put into MySQL data an offensive value that starts a shell command when browsed.
  2. File disclosure: on systems where the UploadDir mecanism is active, read_dump.php can be called with a crafted form; using the fact that the sql_localfile variable is not sanitized can lead to a file disclosure.
fields.affected:
Command execution problem: since phpMyAdmin 2.6.0-pl2. File disclosure problem: 
vulnerable since at least version 2.4.0.
fields.description:
We received a security advisory from Nicolas Gregoire (exaprobe.com) about those vulnerabilities and we wish to thank him for his work. Both vulnerabilites can be exploited only on a web server where PHP safe mode is off. The vulnerabilities apply to those points:

  1. Command execution: since phpMyAdmin 2.6.0-pl2, on a system where external MIME-based transformations are activated, an attacker can put into MySQL data an offensive value that starts a shell command when browsed.
  2. File disclosure: on systems where the UploadDir mecanism is active, read_dump.php can be called with a crafted form; using the fact that the sql_localfile variable is not sanitized can lead to a file disclosure.
fields.solution: We strongly advise everyone to upgrade to version 2.6.1 when released. Meanwhile, setting PHP safe mode to on avoids those problems. If not feasible, you should deactivate MIME-based external transformations and the UploadDir mecanism.
fields.summary:
Two vulnerabilities were found in phpMyAdmin, that may allow
command execution and file disclosure.
fields.references: https://www.exaprobe.com/labs/advisories/esa-2004-1213.html
fields.unaffected:
CVS HEAD has been fixed.
The 2.6.1-rc1 release.
fields.severity:
As any of those vulnerabilites can be used for command execution or file
disclosure, we consider them to be serious (on servers where PHP safe mode is off).

fields._description_rendered: It was possible to create a bookmark which would be executed unintentionally by other users.
fields.description: It was possible to create a bookmark which would be executed unintentionally by other users.
fields.solution:
Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 3.3.9.2 or newer (2.11.11.3 or newer for the older
family) or apply the related patch listed below.
fields.summary: SQL query could be executed under another user.
fields.mitigation:
To use this vulnerability, phpMyAdmin configuration storage needs to be
set up and enabled and bookmarks function needs to be enabled.
fields.references: This issue was found by Michal Čihař.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be critical.

fields._description_rendered: With a crafted view name it is possible to trigger an XSS when dropping the view in view operation page.
fields.affected: Versions 4.1.x (prior to 4.1.14.3) and 4.2.x (prior to 4.2.7.1) are affected.
fields.description: With a crafted view name it is possible to trigger an XSS when dropping the view in view operation page.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 4.1.14.3 or newer, or 4.2.7.1 or newer, or apply the patch listed below.
fields.mitigation: This vulnerability can be triggered only by someone who is logged in to phpMyAdmin, as the usual token protection prevents non-logged-in users from accessing the required pages.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be non critical.

fields._description_rendered: It was possible to display arbitrary text and link to external site using parameters passed to particular script.
fields.description: It was possible to display arbitrary text and link to external site using parameters passed to particular script.
fields.solution:
Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 3.4.0-beta1 or newer or apply patch listed below. Due
to its minor impact, a fix will be included in the next regular release
which is 3.3.10.
fields.references: This issue was reported by Tiger Security Team.
fields.severity:
This issue is considered minor, because the only purpose of affected file is to
display an error message.

fields._description_rendered: With a large number of crafted requests it was possible to infer the CSRF token by a BREACH attack.
fields.affected: Versions 4.0.x (prior to 4.0.10.9), 4.2.x (prior to 4.2.13.2) and 4.3.x (prior to 4.3.11.1) are affected.
fields.description: With a large number of crafted requests it was possible to infer the CSRF token by a BREACH attack.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 4.0.10.9 or newer, or 4.2.13.2 or newer, or 4.3.11.1 or newer, or apply the patch listed below.
fields.summary: Risk of BREACH attack due to reflected parameter.
fields.mitigation:
This vulnerability can only be exploited in the presence of another vulnerability that allows 
the attacker to inject JavaScript into victim's browser.
fields.references: Thanks to Jian Jiang (https://www.linkedin.com/pub/jian-jiang/3a/660/775) and Xiaofeng Zheng (iliwoy@gmail.com) for reporting this vulnerability.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be non critical.

fields._description_rendered: Through a possible bug in PHP, a null byte can truncate the pattern string allowing an attacker to inject the /e modifier causing the preg_replace function to execute its second argument as PHP code.
fields.affected: The 3.4.3 and earlier versions are affected.
fields.description: Through a possible bug in PHP, a null byte can truncate the pattern string allowing an attacker to inject the /e modifier causing the preg_replace function to execute its second argument as PHP code.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 3.3.10.2 or 3.4.3.1 or apply the related patch listed below.
fields.summary: Regular expression quoting issue in Synchronize code.
fields.mitigation:
All PHP versions that were current at the time of the advisory (5.3.6,
5.2.17) on all OS are vulnerable, unless the Suhosin patch has been
installed.

An attacker must be logged in via phpMyAdmin to exploit this problem.
fields.references: This issue was found by Frans Pehrson from Xxor AB. His advisory.
fields.unaffected: Branch 2.11.x is not affected by this.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be serious.

fields._description_rendered:
We received an advisory from Omer Singer, The DigiTrust Group, and we wish to thank him for his work. It was possible to trigger this attack on server_status.php.

Our team fixed also other possible XSS vulnerabilities regarding PHP_SELF, PATH_INFO, REQUEST_URI.
fields.description:
We received an advisory from Omer Singer, The DigiTrust Group, and we wish to thank him for his work. It was possible to trigger this attack on server_status.php.

Our team fixed also other possible XSS vulnerabilities regarding PHP_SELF, PATH_INFO, REQUEST_URI.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 2.11.1.2 or newer.
fields.references: https://www.digitrustgroup.com/advisories/TDG-advisory071015a.html
fields.severity: We consider these vulnerabilities to be serious.

fields._description_rendered: Two days after the release of version 2.7.0, we received a security advisory from Stefan Esser (sesser@hardened-php.net) and we wish to thank him for his work. It is possible to overwrite the global import_blacklist variable to open phpMyAdmin 2.7.0 to those vulnerabilities.
fields.description: Two days after the release of version 2.7.0, we received a security advisory from Stefan Esser (sesser@hardened-php.net) and we wish to thank him for his work. It is possible to overwrite the global import_blacklist variable to open phpMyAdmin 2.7.0 to those vulnerabilities.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 2.7.0-pl1 or newer.
fields.summary: Cross-Site Scripting, local and remote code execution vulnerabilities
fields.references: https://www.hardened-php.net/advisory_252005.110.html
fields.severity: We consider these vulnerabilities to be serious.

fields._description_rendered: Stefan Esser from the Hardened-PHP Project is publishing the Month of PHP Bugs. One of these PHP bugs can be triggered by phpMyAdmin which uses a recursive function in its normal operation.
fields.description: Stefan Esser from the Hardened-PHP Project is publishing the Month of PHP Bugs. One of these PHP bugs can be triggered by phpMyAdmin which uses a recursive function in its normal operation.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 2.10.0.2 or newer. Note that upgrading phpMyAdmin does not protect a server against an attacker that targets other vulnerable PHP applications.
fields.summary: PHP Executor Deep Recursion Stack Overflow
fields.references: https://www.php-security.org/MOPB/MOPB-02-2007.html
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be serious.

fields._description_rendered: Export page uses cookies to remember user settings of file name template. These cookies could be used for cross-site scripting because they were not sanitized sufficiently.
fields.affected:
For 2.11.x: versions before 2.11.9.5.
For 3.x: versions before 3.1.3.1.
fields.description: Export page uses cookies to remember user settings of file name template. These cookies could be used for cross-site scripting because they were not sanitized sufficiently.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 2.11.9.5 or 3.1.3.1 or apply patch listed below.
fields.summary: Cross-site scripting on export page using cookies.
fields.references:
Thanks to Manuel Lopez Gallego (Luisyana) and Santiago Rodríguez Collazo, who
have discovered this issue and reported it to us.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be non critical.

fields._description_rendered: When the files README, ChangeLog or LICENSE have been removed from their original place (possibly by the distributor), the scripts used to display these files can show their full path, leading to possible further attacks.
fields.description: When the files README, ChangeLog or LICENSE have been removed from their original place (possibly by the distributor), the scripts used to display these files can show their full path, leading to possible further attacks.
fields.solution:
Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 3.3.9.1 or newer (2.11.11.2 or newer for the older
family) or apply the related patch listed below.
fields.summary: Path disclosure when some files have been removed.
fields.mitigation:
For the error messages to be displayed, php.ini's error_reporting must be set 
to E_ALL and display_errors must be On (these settings are not recommended 
on a production server in the PHP manual).
fields.references: Thanks to MustLive from Websecurity for reporting this issue.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be non critical.

fields._description_rendered: A logged-in user can be subject of SQL injection through cross site request forgery. Several pages which use affected library in phpMyAdmin are vulnerable and the attack can be made through table parameter.
fields.affected:
For 2.11.x: versions before 2.11.9.4.
For 3.x: versions before 3.1.1.0.
fields.description: A logged-in user can be subject of SQL injection through cross site request forgery. Several pages which use affected library in phpMyAdmin are vulnerable and the attack can be made through table parameter.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 2.11.9.4 or 3.1.1.0 or apply patch listed below.
fields.summary: SQL injection through XSRF on several pages
fields.references: Advisory: https://www.milw0rm.com/exploits/7382
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be serious.

fields._description_rendered: We received a security advisory from Stefan Esser (sesser@hardened-php.net) and we wish to thank him for his work. It was possible to produce XSS via a special URL containing UTF-7 codes
fields.description: We received a security advisory from Stefan Esser (sesser@hardened-php.net) and we wish to thank him for his work. It was possible to produce XSS via a special URL containing UTF-7 codes
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 2.9.0.3 or newer.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be serious.

fields._description_rendered: On systems running PHP 5 before 5.1.2 or PHP 4 before 4.4.2, it is possible to trigger this vulnerability by editing the cookie containing PHP's session id. This can be used to send malicious javascript or redirects.
fields.description: On systems running PHP 5 before 5.1.2 or PHP 4 before 4.4.2, it is possible to trigger this vulnerability by editing the cookie containing PHP's session id. This can be used to send malicious javascript or redirects.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 2.9.2 or newer.
fields.references: https://www.securityfocus.com/archive/1/453432
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be serious.

fields._description_rendered: We received an advisory from Jim Hermann, and we wish to thank him for his work. phpMyAdmin saves sensitive information like the MySQL username and password and the Blowfish secret key in session data, which might be unprotected on a shared host.
fields.description: We received an advisory from Jim Hermann, and we wish to thank him for his work. phpMyAdmin saves sensitive information like the MySQL username and password and the Blowfish secret key in session data, which might be unprotected on a shared host.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 2.11.5.1 or newer.
fields.summary: Credentials disclosure on shared hosts via session data
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be serious.

fields._description_rendered: The import.php script was vulnerable to GLOBALS variable injection. Therefore, an attacker could manipulate any configuration parameter.
fields.description: The import.php script was vulnerable to GLOBALS variable injection. Therefore, an attacker could manipulate any configuration parameter.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 4.0.4.1 or newer, or apply the patch listed below.
fields.mitigation: This vulnerability can be triggered only by someone who logged in to phpMyAdmin, as the usual token protection prevents non-logged-in users from accessing the required form.
fields.references: Thanks to Markus Wulftange of Daimler TSS for reporting this issue.
fields.unaffected: Versions prior to 4.0.0 are not affected.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be serious.

fields._description_rendered: It was possible to conduct a XSS attack using crafted URLs or POST parameters on several pages.
fields.affected:
For 2.11.x: versions before 2.11.10.1 are affected.
For 3.x: versions before 3.3.5.1 are affected.
fields.description: It was possible to conduct a XSS attack using crafted URLs or POST parameters on several pages.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 3.3.5.1 or 2.11.10.1 or newer or apply patch listed below.
fields.summary: Several XSS vulnerabilities were found in the code.
fields.mitigation:
If the auth_type directive is set to 'config' and the directory is not protected,
these attacks are more likely to succeed; otherwise, an attacker would need to obtain a 
valid token via another flaw on the server to be able to exploit these vulnerabilities.
fields.references: Thanks to Aung Khant from YGN Ethical Hacker Group, Myanmar for reporting this issue. See their advisory for more details. After this report the team did audit the code as well and discovered more issues which are fixed as well.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be serious.

fields._description_rendered: Setup script used to generate configuration can be fooled using a crafted POST request to include arbitrary PHP code in generated configuration file. Combined with ability to save files on server, this can allow unauthenticated users to execute arbitrary PHP code.
fields.affected:
For 2.11.x: versions before 2.11.9.5.
For 3.x: versions before 3.1.3.1.
fields.description: Setup script used to generate configuration can be fooled using a crafted POST request to include arbitrary PHP code in generated configuration file. Combined with ability to save files on server, this can allow unauthenticated users to execute arbitrary PHP code.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 2.11.9.5 or 3.1.3.1 or apply patch listed below.
fields.summary: Insufficient output sanitizing when generating configuration file.
fields.mitigation:
Additional steps from administrator are required to actually exploit this
issue (web server writable config directory has to be created).
fields.references: Thanks to Greg Ose (Neohapsis), who has discovered this issue and reported it to us.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be critical.

fields._description_rendered: A vulnerability in the API call to GitHub can be exploited to perform a man-in-the-middle attack.
fields.affected: Versions 4.0.x (prior to 4.0.10.10), 4.2.x (prior to 4.2.13.3), 4.3.x (prior to 4.3.13.1) and 4.4.x (prior to 4.4.6.1) are affected.
fields.description: A vulnerability in the API call to GitHub can be exploited to perform a man-in-the-middle attack.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 4.0.10.10 or newer, or 4.2.13.3 or newer, or 4.3.13.1 or newer, or 4.4.6.1 or newer, or apply the patch listed below.
fields.summary: Vulnerability allowing man-in-the-middle attack on API call to GitHub.
fields.references: Thanks to Maksymilian Arciemowicz of https://cxsecurity.com for reporting this vulnerability.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be serious.

fields._description_rendered: Unauthenticated user was able to display phpinfo output if phpMyAdmin was enabled to show it.
fields.description: Unauthenticated user was able to display phpinfo output if phpMyAdmin was enabled to show it.
fields.solution:
Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 3.4.0-beta1 or newer or apply patch listed below. Due
to its minor impact, a fix will be included in the next regular release
which is 3.3.10.
fields.mitigation:
Default installation is not affected, because $$cfg['ShowPhpInfo'] is false by
default.
fields.references: This issue was reported by Jörg Sommer.
fields.severity:
The issue is considered minor, because this feature is not enabled in default
installation.

fields._description_rendered: It was possible to craft a request that contains XSS by attacking the "table" parameter.
fields.affected: Some versions previous to 2.8.2 suffer from this vulnerability.
fields.description: It was possible to craft a request that contains XSS by attacking the "table" parameter.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 2.8.2.
fields.references: We wish to thank bug@securitynews.ir for informing us in a responsible manner. Their advisory is located at https://securitynews.ir/advisories/phpmyadmin281.txt.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be serious.

fields._description_rendered: With a crafted database, table or a primary/unique key column name it is possible to trigger an XSS when dropping a row from the table. With a crafted column name it is possible to trigger an XSS in the ENUM editor dialog. With a crafted variable name or a crafted value for unit field it is possible to trigger a self-XSS when adding a new chart in the monitor page. With a crafted value for x-axis label it is possible to trigger a self-XSS in the query chart page. With a crafted relation name it is possible to trigger an XSS in table relations page.
fields.affected: Versions 4.0.x (prior to 4.0.10.2), 4.1.x (prior to 4.1.14.3) and 4.2.x (prior to 4.2.7.1) are affected.
fields.description: With a crafted database, table or a primary/unique key column name it is possible to trigger an XSS when dropping a row from the table. With a crafted column name it is possible to trigger an XSS in the ENUM editor dialog. With a crafted variable name or a crafted value for unit field it is possible to trigger a self-XSS when adding a new chart in the monitor page. With a crafted value for x-axis label it is possible to trigger a self-XSS in the query chart page. With a crafted relation name it is possible to trigger an XSS in table relations page.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 4.0.10.2 or newer, or 4.1.14.3 or newer, or 4.2.7.1 or newer, or apply the patches listed below.
fields.summary: Multiple XSS vulnerabilities in browse table, ENUM editor, monitor, query charts and table relations pages
fields.mitigation: These vulnerabilities can be triggered only by someone who is logged in to phpMyAdmin, as the usual token protection prevents non-logged-in users from accessing the required pages.
fields.references: Thanks to Ashutosh Dhundhara for reporting the vulnerability in table relations page.
fields.severity: We consider these vulnerabilities to be non critical.

fields._description_rendered: We received an advisory from Masako Oono of NetAgent Co.,Ltd. via JPCERT/CC Vulnerability Handling Team and we wish to thank them for their work. A logged-in user (when using Microsoft Internet Explorer) can be subject of cross site scripting attack using several variables. This issue does not affect other browsers (tested with Mozilla Firefox, Google Chrome, Konqueror and Apple Safari).
fields.description: We received an advisory from Masako Oono of NetAgent Co.,Ltd. via JPCERT/CC Vulnerability Handling Team and we wish to thank them for their work. A logged-in user (when using Microsoft Internet Explorer) can be subject of cross site scripting attack using several variables. This issue does not affect other browsers (tested with Mozilla Firefox, Google Chrome, Konqueror and Apple Safari).
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 2.11.9.2 or newer.
fields.summary: XSS for Microsoft Internet Explorer on several places
fields.references: Advisory: https://jvn.jp/en/jp/JVN54824688
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be serious.

fields._description_rendered:
We received two bug reports by Maksymilian Arciemowicz about those vulnerabilities and we wish to thank him for his work. The vulnerabilities apply to those points:

  1. css/phpmyadmin.css.php was vulnerable against $$cfg and GLOBALS variable injections. This way, a possible attacker could manipulate any configuration parameter. Using phpMyAdmin's theming mechanism, he was able to include arbitrary files. This is especially dangerous if php is not running in safe mode.
  2. A possible attacker could manipulate phpMyAdmin's localized strings via the URL and inject harmful JavaScript code this way, which could be used for XSS attacks.
fields.affected: Because the theming mechanism was used to perform the remote file inclusion, only the 2.6 branch is affected. Regarding the XSS attacks, we have to assume that all versions down to 1.3.1 are affected.
fields.description:
We received two bug reports by Maksymilian Arciemowicz about those vulnerabilities and we wish to thank him for his work. The vulnerabilities apply to those points:

  1. css/phpmyadmin.css.php was vulnerable against $$cfg and GLOBALS variable injections. This way, a possible attacker could manipulate any configuration parameter. Using phpMyAdmin's theming mechanism, he was able to include arbitrary files. This is especially dangerous if php is not running in safe mode.
  2. A possible attacker could manipulate phpMyAdmin's localized strings via the URL and inject harmful JavaScript code this way, which could be used for XSS attacks.
fields.solution: We strongly advise everyone to upgrade to phpMyAdmin 2.6.1-pl2 or later and to disable register_globals at least for the phpMyAdmin directory.
fields.summary: A variable injection vulnerability was found in phpMyAdmin, that may allow an attacker to conduct Cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks and / or perform remote file inclusion.
fields.references: Bug 1149381 and Bug 1149383
fields.unaffected: CVS HEAD, QA_2_6_0 and QA_2_6_1 have been fixed. The current version, 2.6.1-pl2, should not be vulnerable, either - as long as phpMyAdmin is run with "register_globals = off".
fields.severity: We consider both vulnerabilities to be serious.

fields._description_rendered: It was possible to create a crafted table name that leads to XSS.
fields.description: It was possible to create a crafted table name that leads to XSS.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 3.3.10.1 or 3.4.1 or apply the related patch listed below.
fields.mitigation:
This vulnerability works in the context of a shared phpMyAdmin installation.
The attacker needs to convince a victim to go to the Tracking page that
relates to the crafted table.
fields.references: This issue was found by a person who wishes to be known as "dave b".
fields.unaffected: Older releases than 3.3.0 are not affected.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be serious.

fields._description_rendered: The attacker must trick the victim into clicking a link that reaches phpMyAdmin's table print view script; one of the link's parameters is a crafted table name (the name containing Javascript code).
fields.affected: The 3.4.3.1 and earlier versions are affected.
fields.description: The attacker must trick the victim into clicking a link that reaches phpMyAdmin's table print view script; one of the link's parameters is a crafted table name (the name containing Javascript code).
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 3.3.10.3 or 3.4.3.2 or apply the related patch listed below.
fields.mitigation: The crafted table name must exist (the attacker must have access to create a table on the victim's server).
fields.references: This issue was found by Norman Hippert from The-Wildcat.de
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be minor.

fields._description_rendered: The BLOB streaming feature allowed attacker to include arbitrary files and inject HTTP headers using crafted URL parameters.
fields.affected:
For 2.11.x: not affected as it lacks BLOB streaming support.
For 3.x: versions since 3.1.0.0 and before 3.1.3.1.
fields.description: The BLOB streaming feature allowed attacker to include arbitrary files and inject HTTP headers using crafted URL parameters.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 3.1.3.1 or apply patch listed below.
fields.summary: HTTP Response Splitting and file inclusion vulnerability.
fields.references:
Thanks to Manuel Lopez Gallego (Luisyana) and Santiago Rodríguez Collazo, who
have discovered this issue and reported it to us.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be critical.

fields._description_rendered: When calling schema_export.php with crafted parameters, it is possible to trigger an XSS.
fields.affected: Versions 3.5.x (prior to 3.5.8.2) and 4.0.x (prior to 4.0.4.2) are affected.
fields.description: When calling schema_export.php with crafted parameters, it is possible to trigger an XSS.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 3.5.8.2 or 4.0.4.2 or newer, or apply the patch listed below.
fields.summary: Self-XSS due to unescaped HTML output in schema export.
fields.mitigation: This vulnerability can be triggered only by someone who logged in to phpMyAdmin, as the usual token protection prevents non-logged-in users from accessing the required form.
fields.references: Thanks to 0x721427D8 working with Beyond Security's SecuriTeam Secure Disclosure program for reporting these vulnerabilities.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be non critical.

fields._description_rendered: In some PHP versions, the preg_replace() function can be tricked into executing arbitrary PHP code on the server. This is done by passing a crafted argument as the regular expression, containing a null byte. phpMyAdmin does not correctly sanitize an argument passed to preg_replace() when using the "Replace table prefix" feature, opening the way to this vulnerability.
fields.description: In some PHP versions, the preg_replace() function can be tricked into executing arbitrary PHP code on the server. This is done by passing a crafted argument as the regular expression, containing a null byte. phpMyAdmin does not correctly sanitize an argument passed to preg_replace() when using the "Replace table prefix" feature, opening the way to this vulnerability.
fields.solution: For 3.5.x, upgrade to phpMyAdmin 3.5.8 or newer; for 4.0.x, upgrade to 4.0.0-rc3 or newer. You can also apply the patches listed below.
fields.mitigation: This vulnerability can be triggered only by someone who logged in to phpMyAdmin, as the usual token protection prevents non-logged-in users to access the required form.
fields.references: Thanks to Janek Vind for reporting this issue.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be serious.

fields._description_rendered: We received an advisory from Aung Khant (YGN Ethical Hacker Group), and we wish to thank him for his work. A logged-in user, if abused into clicking a crafted link or loading an attack page, would create a database he did not intend to, or would change his connection character set.
fields.description: We received an advisory from Aung Khant (YGN Ethical Hacker Group), and we wish to thank him for his work. A logged-in user, if abused into clicking a crafted link or loading an attack page, would create a database he did not intend to, or would change his connection character set.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 2.11.7.1 or newer.
fields.summary: XSRF/CSRF for creating a database and modifying user charset
fields.references:
These advisories are available from the reporter:
https://yehg.net/lab/pr0js/advisories/XSRF_CreateDB_inPhpMyAdmin2.11.7.pdf https://yehg.net/lab/pr0js/advisories/XSRF_ConvertCharset_inPhpMyAdmin2.11.7.pdf
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be serious.

fields._description_rendered:
• With a crafted database, table or column name it is possible to trigger an XSS attack in the table browse page.
  • With a crafted ENUM value it is possible to trigger XSS attacks in the table print view and zoom search pages.
  • With a crafted value for font size it is possible to trigger an XSS attack in the home page.
fields.affected: Versions 4.0.x (prior to 4.0.10.6), 4.1.x (prior to 4.1.14.7) and 4.2.x (prior to 4.2.12) are affected.
fields.description:
• With a crafted database, table or column name it is possible to trigger an XSS attack in the table browse page.
  • With a crafted ENUM value it is possible to trigger XSS attacks in the table print view and zoom search pages.
  • With a crafted value for font size it is possible to trigger an XSS attack in the home page.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 4.0.10.6 or newer, or 4.1.14.7 or newer, or 4.2.12 or newer, or apply the patch listed below.
fields.mitigation:
These vulnerabilities can be triggered only by someone who is logged in to phpMyAdmin, as the usual token protection prevents non-logged-in users from accessing the required pages.
Moreover, exploitation of the XSS vulnerability related to the font size requires forgery of the pma_fontsize cookie.
fields.references: Thanks to Johannes Dahse (https://twitter.com/FluxReiners) for reporting XSS vulnerabilities in table browse and home pages.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerabilities to be non critical.

fields._description_rendered: With a crafted column name it is possible to trigger an XSS when dropping the column in table structure page. With a crafted table name it is possible to trigger an XSS when dropping or truncating the table in table operations page.
fields.affected: Versions 4.0.x (prior to 4.0.10.1), 4.1.x (prior to 4.1.14.2) and 4.2.x (prior to 4.2.6) are affected.
fields.description: With a crafted column name it is possible to trigger an XSS when dropping the column in table structure page. With a crafted table name it is possible to trigger an XSS when dropping or truncating the table in table operations page.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 4.0.10.1 or newer, or 4.1.14.2 or newer, or 4.2.6 or newer, or apply the patch listed below.
fields.summary: Multiple XSS in AJAX confirmation messages.
fields.mitigation: This vulnerability can be triggered only by someone who is logged in to phpMyAdmin, as the usual token protection prevents non-logged-in users from accessing the required pages.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be non critical.

fields._description_rendered: With a crafted URL it was possible to trigger an XSS in the redirection mechanism in phpMyAdmin.
fields.description: With a crafted URL it was possible to trigger an XSS in the redirection mechanism in phpMyAdmin.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 4.2.13.1 or newer, or apply the patch listed below.
fields.references: Thanks to Manuel Fernandez of ElevenPaths for reporting this vulnerability.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be non critical.

fields._description_rendered: Some scripts in phpMyAdmin are vulnerable to an HTTP Response Splitting attack.
fields.affected: We did not make an extensive verification on this. Probably all previous versions, and version 2.7.0-beta1 are affected.
fields.description: Some scripts in phpMyAdmin are vulnerable to an HTTP Response Splitting attack.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 2.6.4-pl4.
fields.severity: We consider these vulnerabilities to be serious. However, they can only be triggered on systems running with <tt>register_globals = on</tt>.

fields._description_rendered:
We received a security advisory from Cedric Cochin (netvigilance.com) about those vulnerabilities and we wish to thank him for his work. The vulnerabilities apply to those points:

  1. The logic used to auto-detect the PmaAbsoluteUri parameter can be fooled by adding an extra "/" and a crafted URL.
  2. read_dump.php can be called with a crafted url; using the fact that the zero_rows variable is not sanitized can lead to an attack.
  3. The confirm form (for example after a DROP DATABASE statement) can be used for a XSS attack.
  4. The internal phpMyAdmin parser does not sanitize the error message sent after an error like a punctuation problem.
fields.affected:
Not all previous versions are affected by all vulnerabilities, but it's safe
to say that releases up to and including 2.6.0-pl2 are at risk.
fields.description:
We received a security advisory from Cedric Cochin (netvigilance.com) about those vulnerabilities and we wish to thank him for his work. The vulnerabilities apply to those points:

  1. The logic used to auto-detect the PmaAbsoluteUri parameter can be fooled by adding an extra "/" and a crafted URL.
  2. read_dump.php can be called with a crafted url; using the fact that the zero_rows variable is not sanitized can lead to an attack.
  3. The confirm form (for example after a DROP DATABASE statement) can be used for a XSS attack.
  4. The internal phpMyAdmin parser does not sanitize the error message sent after an error like a punctuation problem.
fields.solution: We strongly advise everyone to upgrade to the next version of phpMyAdmin, which is to be released soon.
fields.summary:
Multiple XSS vulnerability were found in phpMyAdmin, that may allow an
attacker to conduct Cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.
fields.references: https://www.netvigilance.com/html/advisory0005.htm
fields.unaffected:
CVS HEAD has been fixed.
The upcoming 2.6.0-pl3 release.
fields.severity:
As any of those vulnerabilites can be used for a XSS attack, we consider them 
to be serious.

fields._description_rendered: phpMyAdmin allows to use MIME transformations for displaying fields from database. These transformations are not enabled by default (administrator needs to prepare special table for keeping some information and specify it in configuration). One of these transformations allows to pipe field content through external program which needs to be hardcoded in php script. However user can specify parameters to that program and this parameter was not checked for shell meta characters, so attacker could pass there anything from redirection of output to executing any other command.
fields.affected: All releases starting with 2.5.0 up to and including 2.6.0-pl1.
fields.description: phpMyAdmin allows to use MIME transformations for displaying fields from database. These transformations are not enabled by default (administrator needs to prepare special table for keeping some information and specify it in configuration). One of these transformations allows to pipe field content through external program which needs to be hardcoded in php script. However user can specify parameters to that program and this parameter was not checked for shell meta characters, so attacker could pass there anything from redirection of output to executing any other command.
fields.solution:
If you are vulnerable to this issue, easiest fix is to disable external
transformation - just remove file
libraries/transformations/text_plain__external.inc.php. The attached
patch fixes the problem but should only be used by distributors who do
not want to upgrade. Otherwise, we strongly advise everyone to upgrade
to CVS HEAD or to the next version of phpMyAdmin, which is to be
released soon.
fields.summary:
When specifying specially formatted options to external MIME
transformation, an attacker can execute any shell command restricted by
privileges of httpd user.
fields.unaffected:
All releases older than 2.5.0.
CVS HEAD has been fixed.
The upcoming 2.6.0-pl2 release.
fields.severity:
In default setup this feature is not enabled and many hosting providers
run php in safe mode with disabled exec support, which both make them
unaffected by this issue. User also need to be logged in into
phpMyAdmin, what limites range of attackers to users of the server, who
usually also can execute php code directly, so this possibility doesn't
extend his privileges. However this could cause some harm, so we
consider this as important.

fields._description_rendered:
1. It was possible to conduct an XSS attack with a crafted lang or theme parameter.
2. The db parameter was also vulnerable to an XSS attack.
fields.affected:
[1] All 2.8.0.x releases before 2.8.0.4 are affected, previous versions are not.
[2] Some releases before 2.8.0.4 are affected (2.6.2 tested vulnerable).
fields.description:
1. It was possible to conduct an XSS attack with a crafted lang or theme parameter.
2. The db parameter was also vulnerable to an XSS attack.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 2.8.0.4.
fields.references: We wish to thank Sven Vetsch/Disenchant for informing us in a responsible manner. His site is https://www.disenchant.ch.
fields.severity: We consider these vulnerabilities to be serious.

fields._description_rendered: It was possible to manipulate the PHP superglobals (including SESSION) using some of the Swekey authentication code. Also, variables local to the affected Swekey function were at risk. This is similar to PMASA-2011-5.
fields.affected: The 3.4.3.1 and earlier versions are affected.
fields.description: It was possible to manipulate the PHP superglobals (including SESSION) using some of the Swekey authentication code. Also, variables local to the affected Swekey function were at risk. This is similar to PMASA-2011-5.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 3.3.10.3 or 3.4.3.2 or apply the related patch listed below.
fields.summary: Possible superglobal and local variables manipulation in swekey authentication.
fields.mitigation: The Swekey authentication mechanism must be activated (which is not a requirement in the case of PMASA-2011-5).
fields.references: This issue was found by Frans Pehrson from Xxor AB.His advisory.
fields.unaffected: Branch 2.11.x is not affected by this.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be critical.

fields._description_rendered: The show_config_errors.php scripts did not validate the presence of the configuration file, so an error message shows the full path of this file, leading to possible further attacks.
fields.description: The show_config_errors.php scripts did not validate the presence of the configuration file, so an error message shows the full path of this file, leading to possible further attacks.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 3.4.10.2 or newer or apply the related patch listed below.
fields.summary: Path disclosure due to missing verification of file presence.
fields.mitigation:
For the error messages to be displayed, php.ini's error_reporting must be set 
to E_ALL and display_errors must be On (these settings are not recommended 
on a production server in the PHP manual).
fields.references: Thanks to Mateusz Goik from AliantSoft for reporting this issue.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be non critical.

fields._description_rendered: Due to not properly validating the version.json file, which is fetched from the phpMyAdmin.net website, could lead to an XSS attack, if a crafted version.json file would be presented.
fields.affected: Versions 3.5.x (prior to 3.5.8.2) and 4.0.x (prior to 4.0.4.2) are affected.
fields.description: Due to not properly validating the version.json file, which is fetched from the phpMyAdmin.net website, could lead to an XSS attack, if a crafted version.json file would be presented.
fields.solution:
Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 3.5.8.2 or 4.0.4.2 or newer or apply the patches
listed below.
fields.summary: If a crafted version.json would be presented, an XSS could be introduced.
fields.mitigation: This vulnerability can only be exploited with a combination of complicated techniques and tricking the user to visit a page.
fields.references: Thanks to Emanuel Bronshtein for reporting these issues.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability serious.

fields._description_rendered:
Reporter wrote that he found following issues within phpMyAdmin code (each issue is followed by our comment):

  • Directory transversal attack - Already fixed in 2.5.0 release
  • Remote local file retrieving - Author didn't show any proof of this
  • Remote internal directory listing - It was possible to retrieve listing of phpMyAdmin directory, however content of this directory is publicly known. This was fixed for upcoming 2.5.2 release.
  • XSS and Path disclosures - Most of these issues were fixed in 2.5.0 release, however some of these were still there and these will be fixed in upcoming 2.5.2 release.
  • Information encoding weakness - We believe that an exploit for this weakness would be difficult to achieve. However version 2.5.2 now encrypts the password with the well-known blowfish algorithm.
fields.affected:
All releases up to and not including 2.5.2. See description for more
details about this.
fields.description:
Reporter wrote that he found following issues within phpMyAdmin code (each issue is followed by our comment):

  • Directory transversal attack - Already fixed in 2.5.0 release
  • Remote local file retrieving - Author didn't show any proof of this
  • Remote internal directory listing - It was possible to retrieve listing of phpMyAdmin directory, however content of this directory is publicly known. This was fixed for upcoming 2.5.2 release.
  • XSS and Path disclosures - Most of these issues were fixed in 2.5.0 release, however some of these were still there and these will be fixed in upcoming 2.5.2 release.
  • Information encoding weakness - We believe that an exploit for this weakness would be difficult to achieve. However version 2.5.2 now encrypts the password with the well-known blowfish algorithm.
fields.solution:
We strongly advise everyone to upgrade to CVS HEAD or to the next
version of phpMyAdmin, which is to be released soon.
fields.summary:
Several security issues were reported to BugTraq mailing list. However
most of these issues were already fixed some time ago.
fields.references: https://www.securityfocus.com/archive/1/325641
fields.unaffected:
CVS HEAD has been fixed.
The upcoming 2.5.2 release.
fields.severity:
Only really problematic issue in current versions is XSS attack, which
in combination with clever javascript could be used to steal
authentication, but this would require to force user to click on link
supplied by attacker. Therefore we consider this issue as important.

fields._description_rendered: With a crafted file name it is possible to trigger an XSS in the error reporting page.
fields.affected: Versions 4.1.x (prior to 4.1.14.7) and 4.2.x (prior to 4.2.12) are affected.
fields.description: With a crafted file name it is possible to trigger an XSS in the error reporting page.
fields.solution: Upgrade to 4.1.14.7 or newer, or 4.2.12 or newer, or apply the patch listed below.
fields.summary: XSS vulnerability in error reporting functionality.
fields.mitigation: This vulnerability can be triggered only by someone who is logged in to phpMyAdmin, as the usual token protection prevents non-logged-in users from accessing the required page.
fields.references: Thanks to Johannes Dahse (https://twitter.com/FluxReiners) for reporting this vulnerability.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be non critical.

fields._description_rendered: We received a security advisory from laurent gaffié and we wish to thank him for his work. It was possible to disclose path by passing an array to several parameters.
fields.description: We received a security advisory from laurent gaffié and we wish to thank him for his work. It was possible to disclose path by passing an array to several parameters.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 2.9.1.1 or newer.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be serious.

fields._description_rendered: We received an advisory from Laurent Gaffié and we wish to thank him for his work. It was possible to trigger these attacks on db_create.php and index.php.
fields.description: We received an advisory from Laurent Gaffié and we wish to thank him for his work. It was possible to trigger these attacks on db_create.php and index.php.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 2.9.2 or newer.
fields.severity: We consider these vulnerabilities to be serious.

fields._description_rendered: By deceiving a logged-in user to click on a crafted URL, it is possible to perform remote code execution and in some cases, create a root account due to a DOM based XSS vulnerability in the micro history feature.
fields.affected: Versions 4.0.x (prior to 4.0.10.3), 4.1.x (prior to 4.1.14.4) and 4.2.x (prior to 4.2.8.1) are affected.
fields.description: By deceiving a logged-in user to click on a crafted URL, it is possible to perform remote code execution and in some cases, create a root account due to a DOM based XSS vulnerability in the micro history feature.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 4.0.10.3 or newer, or 4.1.14.4 or newer, or 4.2.8.1 or newer, or apply the patches listed below.
fields.summary: XSRF/CSRF due to DOM based XSS in the micro history feature
fields.references: Thanks to Olivier Beg (https://www.olivierbeg.nl) for reporting the vulnerability.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be critical.

fields._description_rendered: We received a security advisory from Oriol Torrent Santiago and we wish to thank him for his work and report. The convcharset parameter was not correctly validated, opening the door to a XSS attack.
fields.description: We received a security advisory from Oriol Torrent Santiago and we wish to thank him for his work and report. The convcharset parameter was not correctly validated, opening the door to a XSS attack.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 2.6.2-rc1 or newer.
fields.references: https://www.arrelnet.com/advisories/adv20050403.html
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be serious.

fields._description_rendered: The setup script used to generate configuration can be fooled using a crafted POST request to include arbitrary PHP code in generated configuration file. Combined with the ability to save files on the server, this can allow unauthenticated users to execute arbitrary PHP code.
fields.description: The setup script used to generate configuration can be fooled using a crafted POST request to include arbitrary PHP code in generated configuration file. Combined with the ability to save files on the server, this can allow unauthenticated users to execute arbitrary PHP code.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 2.11.10.1 or apply the patch listed below.
fields.summary: Insufficient output sanitizing when generating configuration file.
fields.mitigation:
Additional steps from administrator are required to actually exploit this
issue (a web server writable config directory has to be created).
fields.references: Thanks to Takeshi Terada of Mitsui Bussan Secure Directions, Inc., who has discovered this issue and reported it to us. See the reported bug for more details.
fields.unaffected: Branch 3.x is not affected by this.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be critical.

fields._description_rendered: When marking a crafted database or table name as favorite or having it in recent tables, it is possible to trigger an XSS.
fields.affected: All versions since 4.2.0 and prior to 4.2.4 are affected.
fields.description: When marking a crafted database or table name as favorite or having it in recent tables, it is possible to trigger an XSS.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 4.2.4 or newer, or apply the patch listed below.
fields.summary: Self-XSS due to unescaped HTML output in recent/favorite tables navigation.
fields.mitigation: This vulnerability can be triggered only by someone who is logged in to phpMyAdmin, as the usual token protection prevents non-logged-in users from accessing the required form.
fields.references: Thanks to Madhura Jayaratne and Chirayu Chiripal for reporting this vulnerability.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be non critical.

fields._description_rendered: Fixed filtering of a file path in the MIME-type transformation code, which allowed for directory traversal.
fields.affected: The 3.4.3 and earlier versions are affected.
fields.description: Fixed filtering of a file path in the MIME-type transformation code, which allowed for directory traversal.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 3.3.10.2 or 3.4.3.1 or apply the related patch listed below.
fields.references: This issue was found by Frans Pehrson from Xxor AB. His advisory.
fields.unaffected: Branch 2.11.x is not affected by this.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be serious.

fields._description_rendered: In the 'relational schema' code a parameter was not sanitized before being used to concatenate a class name.
fields.description: In the 'relational schema' code a parameter was not sanitized before being used to concatenate a class name.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 3.4.3.2 or apply the related patch listed below.
fields.summary: Local file inclusion vulnerability and code execution.
fields.mitigation: An attacker must be logged in via phpMyAdmin to exploit this problem.
fields.references: This issue was found by Norman Hippert from The-Wildcat.de
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be critical.

fields._description_rendered: To display information about the current phpMyAdmin version on the main page, a piece of JavaScript is fetched from the phpmyadmin.net website in non-SSL mode. A man-in-the-middle could modify this script on the wire to cause mischief.
fields.description: To display information about the current phpMyAdmin version on the main page, a piece of JavaScript is fetched from the phpmyadmin.net website in non-SSL mode. A man-in-the-middle could modify this script on the wire to cause mischief.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 3.5.3 or newer or apply the patches listed below. The fix involves fetching a JSON file rather than a JavaScript file.
fields.summary: Fetching the version information from a non-SSL site is vulnerable to a MITM attack.
fields.references: Thanks to Mike Cardwell for reporting this issue and suggesting workarounds.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be non critical.

fields._description_rendered: Via a crafted MIME-type transformation parameter, an attacker can perform a local file inclusion.
fields.description: Via a crafted MIME-type transformation parameter, an attacker can perform a local file inclusion.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 3.4.3.2 or apply the related patch listed below.
fields.mitigation: The phpMyAdmin's configuration storage mechanism must be configured for this attack to work.
fields.references: This issue was found by Norman Hippert from The-Wildcat.de
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be serious.

fields._description_rendered:
We received an advisory from Omer Singer, The DigiTrust Group, and we wish to thank him for his work. It was possible to create a malicious database name that contains XSS code.

Our team fixed another XSS vulnerability regarding database names.
fields.description:
We received an advisory from Omer Singer, The DigiTrust Group, and we wish to thank him for his work. It was possible to create a malicious database name that contains XSS code.

Our team fixed another XSS vulnerability regarding database names.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 2.11.2.1 or newer.
fields.references: For the first issue: https://www.digitrustgroup.com/advisories/tdg-advisory071108a.html
fields.severity: We consider these vulnerabilities to be serious.

fields._description_rendered: phpMyAdmin created temporary files with predictable file name.
fields.description: phpMyAdmin created temporary files with predictable file name.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 3.0.0 or 2.11.10.
fields.references: We wish to thank to Thijs Kinkhorst for pointing out this issue.
fields.unaffected: 3.x releases are not affected.
fields.severity: We consider these vulnerabilities to be not critical.

fields._description_rendered: It was possible to manipulate the PHP session superglobal using some of the Swekey authentication code. This could open a path for other attacks.
fields.affected: The 3.4.3 and earlier versions are affected.
fields.description: It was possible to manipulate the PHP session superglobal using some of the Swekey authentication code. This could open a path for other attacks.
fields.solution: Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 3.3.10.2 or 3.4.3.1 or apply the related patch listed below.
fields.summary: Possible session manipulation in Swekey authentication.
fields.references: This issue was found by Frans Pehrson from Xxor AB. His advisory.
fields.unaffected: Branch 2.11.x is not affected by this.
fields.severity: We consider this vulnerability to be critical.

fields._description_rendered: When the TextLinkTransformationPlugin is used to create a link to an object when displaying the contents of a table, the object name is not properly escaped, which could lead to an XSS, if the object name has a crafted value.
fields.description: When the TextLinkTransformationPlugin is used to create a link to an object when displaying the contents of a table, the object name is not properly escaped, which could lead to an XSS, if the object name has a crafted value.
fields.solution:
Upgrade to phpMyAdmin 4.0.4.2 or newer or apply the patches
listed below.
fields.summary: XSS vulnerability when a text to link transformation is used.
fields.mitigation:
